prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band3_1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It covers HCO+, HCN, C2H, HC3N

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolutionOur velocity resolution (< 4km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities in the expected line width of 50 km/s. We do not lower the resolution further because we could obtain some velocity
-rep. spec. window width We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Ang res.: We use 1.1" (~190 pc) in order to efficiently capture emission from two nuclei of a similar size. It also matches with the survey of Arp 220 (Martin et al. cycle 1 + proposed in this cycle 2015.1.00167.S) in length scale for a reasonable comparison between two surveys.
-LAS: Our target molecules are usually coming from compact regions (i.e., two nuclei and the interaction region) expect CO isotopologues. Therefore we choose 7" for LAS except for CO isotopologues.

Cycle 0 observation by Sakamoto et al. (2014) detected CH3CCH with 4 mJy/beam within the velocity resolution 30 km/s. Assuming emission of this complex molecule mostly come from compact nuclei, to detect molecules with about the same intensity with 10 sigma, we need 0.4 mJy/beam.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Both nuclei have line FWHM of 150-200 km/s (Sakamoto et al. 2014). Our velocity resolution of 30 km/s allows enough S/N for molecules with weak emission, but fine enough to get some velocity information.
We hope to obtain velocity information for lines intense enough. Our data rate in this science goal is 12.21 GB, which only slightly exceeds the limit of 12GB.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band3_2
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It covers N2H+, HNC, HC3N, H2CS

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band3_3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: It covers CH3OH, 13CO, C18O, HC3N, CH3CN, HNCO

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
-spec. resolutionOur velocity resolution (< 4km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities in the expected line width of 50 km/s. We do not lower the resolution further because we could obtain some velocity
-rep. spec. window width We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Ang res.: We use 1.1" (~190 pc) in order to efficiently capture emission from two nuclei of a similar size. It also matches with the survey of Arp 220 (Martin et al. cycle 1 + proposed in this cycle 2015.1.00167.S) in length scale for a reasonable comparison between two surveys.

Cycle 0 observation by Sakamoto et al. (2014) detected CH3CCH with 4 mJy/beam within the velocity resolution 30 km/s. Assuming emission of this complex molecule mostly come from compact nuclei, to detect molecules with about the same intensity with 10 sigma, we need 0.4 mJy/beam.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Both nuclei have line FWHM of 150-200 km/s (Sakamoto et al. 2014). Our velocity resolution of 30 km/s allows enough S/N for molecules with weak emission, but fine enough to get some velocity information.
We hope to obtain velocity information for lines intense enough. Our data rate in this science goal is 12.21 GB, which only slightly exceeds the limit of 12GB.

-spec. resolution:Our velocity resolution (~2.5 km/s) is fine enough to examine the velocity-integrated intensities as well as some velocity information in the expected line width of 50 km/s within the data rate limit.
-rep. spec. window width We use the bandwidth of 1875 MHz to include as many lines as possible because our goal is to obtain as many molecular tracers as possible.

-Ang res.: We use 1.1" (~190 pc) in order to efficiently capture emission from two nuclei of a similar size. It also matches with the survey of Arp 220 (Martin et al. cycle 1 + proposed in this cycle 2015.1.00167.S) in length scale for a reasonable comparison between two surveys.
-LAS: In Sakamoto et al. (2014) in SMA observation, 13CO seems to spread to ~ 10".

According to the Cycle 0 observation by Sakamoto et al. (2014), 13CO (2-1) by SMA observation shows 140mJy/beam within 2.1"x1.7" beam. In Arp 220, one of our target molecules CH3CCH has about 5% intensity of 13CO. Assuming that the 13CO emission come from the compact regions, we need 0.7mJy for the 10 sigma detection of CH3CCH.
Bandwidth used for sensitivity calculation: Both nuclei have line FWHM of 150-200 km/s (Sakamoto et al. 2014). Our velocity resolution of 30 km/s allows enough S/N for molecules with weak emission, but fine enough to get some velocity information.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We propose to fill a large gap in extragalactic spectral surveys by observing NGC 3256, the most luminous galaxy within z=0.01. This galaxy is the brightest on the sky among the luminous infrared galaxies (LIRGs) powered by merger-induced galaxy-wide starburst. This class, whose energy source is known to be starburst (not an AGN), is the majority of the luminous LIRGs (11.5 ~ < log L(IR) < 12). Also, they are ~10 times more luminous than NGC 253 and M82. Yet disproportionally little attention has been paid for its astrochemical properties.
We will observe key molecular tracers in multiple transitions in Bands 3 and 6, and compare the derived chemical abundances to those in Arp 220, a ULIRG having very compact energy source(s), NGC 253, a local starburst, and the Seyfert nucleus of NGC 1068, as well as other sources with spectral scans. Principal component analysis will reveal the effects of merger and high-luminosity in the chemical composition.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Institute of Astronomy and Astrophysics, Academia Sinica
IRAM Grenoble, Institute of Millimetric Radioastronomy (IRAM)
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
Earth and Space Sciences, Chalmers University of Technology
